channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - World
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2018 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Anger in Iran as US reimposes sanctions
New Caledonia votes to stay with France
item.description: The tiny Pacific territory of New Caledonia has voted to remain part of France in a long-awaited independence referendum which saw a much closer final result than expected.

item.title: North Korea issues new nuclear threat
item.description: As the United States and North Korea prepare for another round of high-level talks this week, Pyongyang's increasingly heated rhetoric has analysts worried that the stalemate between the two sides could lead to a breakdown in negotiations.

item.title: South Koreans are working themselves to death
item.description: It takes Park Hyun-suk, a widow who lost her husband to gwarosa -- the Korean word for death by overwork -- a long time to find a photo of them together.

item.title: 29 people die in Italy's storms and flooding
item.description: With the deaths of 12 people in Sicily, the death toll in Italy's historic flooding has grown to 29, the country's interior minister said.

item.title: Inside the world's oldest pencil company
item.description: Faber-Castell makes some 2 billion pencils across 120 different colors every year. We took a look inside their factory.

item.title: China is crushing Europe's electric car dreams
item.description: Europe gave the world some of its top automakers, but it's losing out to China in the race to define the industry's future.

item.title: US sanctions failed to shut down Iran oil exports
item.description: US sanctions have failed so far to shut down Iranian oil exports, and some countries are reportedly close to being granted exemptions to allow them to continue buying from Tehran without fear of punishment.

item.title: Why China's tech giants are cozying up to the Communist Party
item.description: China's biggest ride-hailing company has a new plan to beef up customer service: hire 1,000 members of the ruling Communist Party.

item.title: The story of Apple and the iPhone in 3 charts
item.description: Get a good look at this iPhone sales chart, because it's the last one you'll ever see.

item.title: The legs that stopped a nation
Rose Triumphs, Khachanov Dominates in Paris
item.description: Justin Rose defends his Turkish Airlines Open title and Karen Khachanov wins the Rolex Paris Masters.

item.title: As anti-doping body and athletes bicker, have the cheats won?
item.description: These are testing times in the fight to keep sport clean, with a number of leading athletes seemingly pitted against the organization that's responsible for looking after anti-doping.

item.title: Meet the British teenager set to make F1 history
item.description: There were no tears or hysterical celebrations for Lando Norris on the most significant Sunday yet of his young life, just inner contentment at a childhood ambition achieved. Perhaps it should be of no surprise that a teenager who spends his time racing at body-rattling speeds kept his cool when told he was to become the youngest Formula One driver in British history.

item.title: Woman coach breaks glass ceiling in college football
item.description: As a woman working in a male-dominated field, Callie Brownson isn't a stranger to the word "no." But since getting a "yes," her ascension has been swift.

item.title: Last of the samurai swordsmiths
item.description: At Fusahiro Shimojima's workshop, in the industrial city of Saitama, fires rage in small pits and an earthen floor absorbs the din of hammering. The 44-year-old Japanese swordsmith pounds the nascent blade of his newest creation, sending molten sparks flying majestically into air.

item.title: Chinese buildings designed by robots
item.description: Amid population growth and unprecedented urbanization, China's rise has been enabled by its ability to build quickly and cheaply. But meeting the country's construction demands has come at the expense of architectural identity, according to Philip Yuan, founder of the firm Archi-Union Architects.

item.title: AI-produced artwork makes history
item.description: "Edmond de Belamy" has made history as the first work of art produced by artificial intelligence to be sold at auction.

item.title: Why these luxury buckets sell for thousands
item.description: It's hard to imagine the humble bucket being a work of art, but those made by Shuji Nakagawa in his Kyoto studio go for thousands of dollars and have a loyal following.

item.title: Inside the world's largest underwater restaurant
item.description: Five meters below the surface of the North Sea, near the southernmost tip of Norway, Europe's first underwater restaurant is nearing completion. The 110-foot long structure, an oblique concrete slab that looks like a sunken periscope, was submerged in July 2018 and work is now underway to complete the interiors, in anticipation of the public opening in spring 2019.

item.title: Totally new jetliner unveiled for US fliers
item.description: For some folks, flying on a brand new airliner is almost as exciting as riding in a spanking new car.

item.title: The fire that's been burning for 4,000 years
Custom KitKat shop opens in Japan
item.description: These days, you can customize your car, your house and your clothes. So why not your favorite sweet?

item.title: The hotel at the end of the world
item.description: Inside its grounds, the Qasr Al Sarab hotel has all you'd expect from a high-class UAE resort -- luxury villas, private pools, top-notch restaurants and a fully equipped spa.

item.title: Beach bar has incredible moving roof
item.description: Who knew a roof could become an Internet sensation?

item.title: They're changing the world through kindness
item.description: Meet 10 remarkable trailblazers who have truly changed the world. Each one has found a way to use their knowledge and inspiration to help countless others.

item.title: Needy families slept on floors until he created a solution
item.description: As part of his medical training, Dr. Ricardo Pun-Chong spent time doing rounds in hospitals throughout Lima, the capital of Peru.

item.title: Her app sends unwanted food to hungry Americans
item.description: Maria Rose Belding grew up working in her church's food pantry in her small Iowa hometown.

item.title: Goodbye, old iPhone: This could be 40X better
